claim: Africa is the continent, not the country, with the most poverty.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest number of people living below the international poverty line of $1.90 per day.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest number of people living below the international poverty line of $1.90 per day.
The poverty line of $1.90 per day is outdated and does not account for cost-of-living variations across regions.
The $1.90 poverty line is adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP), making it a globally comparable metric.
Other continents, like Asia, have larger populations, so absolute numbers may not reflect the proportion of poverty.
Even when adjusted for population proportion, Sub-Saharan Africa still has the highest poverty rate globally.
Poverty measurements often exclude informal economies and subsistence living, which are prevalent in Africa.
International organizations like the World Bank include informal sector estimates in poverty calculations.

supporting.text: More than half of the world's poorest countries by GDP per capita are located in Africa.

attacks.text: More than half of the world's poorest countries by GDP per capita are located in Africa.
GDP per capita does not fully capture poverty, as it ignores inequality and cost of living differences.
Even with inequality adjustments, African nations still dominate the bottom rankings of poverty indices.
Some non-African countries (e.g., Haiti, Afghanistan) have extreme poverty levels comparable to the worst African cases.
These exceptions are numerically insignificant compared to the concentration of poverty in Africa.

supporting.text: Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for the largest share of global extreme poverty, according to World Bank data.

attacks.text: Sub-Saharan Africa accounts for the largest share of global extreme poverty, according to World Bank data.
The World Bank's definition of 'extreme poverty' is based on income thresholds that may not fully capture multidimensional poverty.
Multidimensional poverty indices from the UNDP confirm that Sub-Saharan Africa still leads in poverty even when considering non-income factors.
Other regions like South Asia have comparable poverty rates when measured by population density rather than geographic area.
Per capita poverty rates in Sub-Saharan Africa remain higher than South Asia, reinforcing the original claim.

supporting.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, with over 40% of its population living in extreme poverty.

attacks.text: Africa has the highest poverty rate among all continents, with over 40% of its population living in extreme poverty.
Poverty rates in Africa vary significantly by country, and some regions have lower poverty rates than parts of other continents.
Even with regional variations, the continental average poverty rate in Africa remains the highest globally.
Other continents, such as Asia, have larger absolute numbers of people in poverty despite lower rates.
The claim focuses on poverty rate (percentage), not absolute numbers, making Africa's higher rate still valid.

supporting.text: The United Nations identifies Africa as the region with the most severe and widespread poverty challenges.

attacks.text: The United Nations identifies Africa as the region with the most severe and widespread poverty challenges.
Poverty is measured differently across regions, and some Asian countries have higher absolute numbers of impoverished people.
The UN's methodology accounts for regional disparities and still identifies Africa as having the most severe poverty challenges.
Other regions, like parts of South Asia, have comparable poverty rates when adjusted for population density.
Africa's poverty is more widespread geographically, affecting more countries than any other region.

supporting.text: Africa's poverty levels are exacerbated by factors such as conflict, climate change, and limited access to education and healthcare.

attacks.text: Africa's poverty levels are exacerbated by factors such as conflict, climate change, and limited access to education and healthcare.
Other continents, such as parts of Asia and South America, also face extreme poverty due to similar systemic issues.
Africa's poverty is uniquely severe due to historical exploitation, such as colonialism, which has had long-lasting economic impacts.
Poverty metrics often fail to account for informal economies and subsistence living, which are prevalent in Africa.
Even with informal economies, Africa still reports the highest rates of extreme poverty by standard international measures.
Some African countries, like Botswana and Mauritius, have significantly reduced poverty through effective governance and economic policies.
While exceptions exist, the continental average still shows Africa as the region with the highest poverty rates globally.
